metadata.title: Early career psychiatrists’ perspectives on the mental health impact and care of the COVID-19 pandemic across the world

body_text.text: The Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-Cov2) virus and its associated illness, termed COVID-19, have led to a global health crisis of unparalleled proportions (Wang et al., 2020b). Deemed by the World Health Organization (WHO) as a pandemic on March 11th, 2020, COVID-19 has led to a plethora of follow-on effects, with one country after another coming under lockdown so as to bring the spread under control (Iacobucci, 2020; Lau et al., 2020; Pulla, 2020). The viruses, and attendant measures to check its spread, have led to many countries reporting increased mortality and morbidity rates, whilst facing huge economic losses, social disruption, physical distancing, and additionally the potential for a widespread increase in mental health issues (Dong and Bouey, 2020; Ho et al., 2020; Torales et al., 2020a).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The literature review, searching government websites and expert opinion from psychiatrists confirmed that there is lack of evidence based guidelines and clear intervention plans, which may have limited the effectiveness and accessibility of interventions in this pandemic (Jung and Jun, 2020; Lima et al., 2020). Most mental health professionals (MHP) have attempted to provide primary mental health care (advisory, psychotherapy or counseling and pharmacological treatment) through their professional organization or as volunteers (Dong and Bouey, 2020; Jung and Jun, 2020). These efforts were not well organized, stage-specific nor directed towards the specific needs of the general population and health care workers (HCW) (Dong and Bouey, 2020; Lima et al., 2020; Xiang et al., 2020).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Pandemic, as a form of disaster, is a complex and unpredictable situation leaving limited opportunities to conduct well planned, organized and controlled clinical trials (Benight and McFarlane, 2007). Most of the published studies we found were cross-sectional in nature, phase-specific (i.e. either first phase of disaster or post-disaster phase) and limited to certain populations (e.g. health care workers)(Brooks et al., 2020; Lai et al., 2020; Makwana, 2019; Math et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2020a), which has limited value to develop comprehensive strategies to address the mental health issues during pandemic. This could be due to the current theoretical framework or recommendation to address the mental health needs of the affected population (Math et al., 2015; Ornell et al., 2020; Purgato et al., 2018). The Young‘s theoretical framework is one of the commonly used for disaster research. It includes heroic, honeymoon, disillusionment and restoration phase of disaster with preventive, curative and preparedness as a treatment strategies (Math et al., 2015; Math et al., 2008). However, it is not disaster-specific (e.g. earthquake, terrorist attack, infectious disease), so may have limited value in the current pandemic. In addition, most national and international recommendations for mental health care during disasters are vertical in nature. These recommendations or frameworks do not consider the use of recently available digital technology and global plan for mental health (Math et al., 2015). There is a need to reconsider the current theoretical frameworks and provide alternative approaches to conduct future disaster research projects(Benight and McFarlane, 2007; Dong and Bouey, 2020); however limited attempts have been made to provide new or alternative framework at global and national disaster preparedness.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: To address these limitations of previous theoretical or conceptual frameworks and to develop global evidence-based measures, we attempted to develop a conceptual framework to address mental health care during pandemics from an early career psychiatrists' perspective.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This phase was directed towards assessing the current scenario of mental health and approaches (Preventive and therapeutic, if any) adopted. The ECPs were requested to share information about their country (economic status, number of cases & deaths from COVID-19 at the time of writing), preparatory plans, measures (e.g. innovative, replicable or scalable) adopted or available for the future, as well as to discuss pre-existing infrastructure, ongoing training, and funding.
body_text.section: Phase-1 Preliminary Assessment ::: Material and Methods

body_text.text: The lead (RR) and co-lead (FA) developed a preliminary conceptual framework (epidemiology, interventions and outcome) based on a comprehensive review of existing literature and the responses submitted by country representatives. The literature review was focused on identifying relevant existing information related to epidemiology, interventions, opinions, and recommendations. This information formed the basis of a preliminary conceptual model which we attempted to categorize as per WHO’s pandemic preparedness plan (Droogers et al., 2019).
body_text.section: Phase-2: Development of an A Priori Conceptual Framework ::: Material and Methods

body_text.text: An A Priori Conceptual Framework was shared with the country representatives for comments, suggestions and modifications and was modified iteratively based on consensus and feedback. The Consensus decision making (>70% representative agreeable) was adopted for final inclusion.
body_text.section: Phase -3: Mental Health Preparedness and Action Framework (MHPAF) ::: Material and Methods

body_text.text: As there was no direct involvement of human participants, or utilization of identifiable data, ethical approval from local institutional review boards was not sought.
body_text.section: Ethics ::: Material and Methods

body_text.text: All WHO regions were represented in the sample of early career psychiatrists. There were five countries respectively from lower middle income (India, Nigeria, Indonesia, Egypt and Tunisia), four were from upper middle income countries (Colombia, Brazil, Iran and Lebanon) and six were from high income countries (Italy, Spain, United States of America, Portugal, Singapore, New Zealand), and one was non-UN (United nations) country (Kosovo). All countries were in stage 5-6 as per WHO- global influenza preparedness plan (WHO-GIPP). All countries were reporting local transmission except Nigeria (Mainly Imported) and Italy (Mixed) (WHO, 2020). The countries differed from each other in terms of the occurrence of the first case, number of confirmed cases, rates of mortality and measures adopted (WHO, 2020).
body_text.section: Baseline characteristics ::: Results

body_text.text:
EEC may have two-peaks as described below. a)
First peak: It may be associated with inadequate communication, misinformation, myths and fake news. Rapid or exponential growth of COVID-19 cases may cause fear, distress anxiety, depression, sleep disorders, panic attacks or adjustment disorders, and suicidal ideation and/or behavior (Ho et al., 2020; Li et al., 2020b; Lima et al., 2020).b)
Dipping point: Some countries may show a dipping point, indicative of community resilience, with a rapid reduction of distress after the first peak.c)
Second peak: This can be unpredicted and complex, occurring due to the death of loved ones, economic damage and marked social disruption. The predominant disorder may be post-traumatic stress disorder, grief, depression and relapse of pre-existing mental health conditions (Liu et al., 2020; Neria et al., 2008).
body_text.section: Components of the Emotional Epidemic Curve ::: A Conceptual Model of Emotional Epidemic Curve ::: Results

body_text.text: It includes the description of the stages of pandemic, the role of the WHO and recommendations for before and during a pandemic (WHO, 2005; WHO, 2009). It classifies the pandemic in six phases and includes a post-peak and post- pandemic period. The phase 1-3 measures are directed towards increasing the health care capacity through training, development of infrastructure and a surveillance system, while phase 4 to 6 includes the coordination, support, response and community mitigation efforts. Community mitigation efforts are vital public response measures aimed to halt transmission of influenza virus. It includes social distancing (e.g. travel restriction, working from home, closing of school, city or country lockdown), masks, respiratory and hand washing hygiene (WHO, 2005).
body_text.section: Brief summary of the WHO -GIPP ::: Mental Health Preparedness and Action Framework (MHPAF) ::: Results

body_text.text: MHPAF is mainly focused on development of a Mental Health Surveillance System (MHSS) to understand the epidemiology of mental disorders during pandemic, as well as to develop possible measures directed towards reducing the possible burden of mental disorder and the use of appropriate technology. We have discussed these components in depth subsequently.
body_text.section: Components of MHPAF ::: Mental Health Preparedness and Action Framework (MHPAF) ::: Results

body_text.text: In our opinion, MHPAF can address mental health issues more effectively than existing approaches. Real time data obtained through MHSS can help to prioritize interventions (e.g. population at risk, HCW), with dynamic modifications being made based on the changing needs of the population.
body_text.section: Probable Effect of MHPAF on the Emotional Epidemic Curve ::: Results

body_text.text: The effect can be categorized as follows:
body_text.section: Probable Effect of MHPAF on the Emotional Epidemic Curve ::: Results

body_text.text:
COVID-19 Epidemic Curve: MHPAF along with WHO-GIPP may have an additive effect on flattening the epidemic curve, allowing more time to the first response and increasing the capacity or performance of the healthcare system (Fig. 3
).
body_text.section: Probable Effect of MHPAF on the Emotional Epidemic Curve ::: Results

body_text.text:
Emotional Epidemic Curve (EEC): MHPAF integrated with global influenza preparedness may reduce the height of the first and second peak of EEC, and may help in flattening of the epidemic cure, and thus may reduce the prevalence of post-peak or post-pandemic disorders (Fig. 4
). Together, the performance or capacity of the mental health system can be well preserved.
body_text.section: Probable Effect of MHPAF on the Emotional Epidemic Curve ::: Results

body_text.text: It is noted that in the midst of a pandemic, people may experience an ‘emotional contagion’ (i.e., the spread of mood and affect through populations by the direct induction of emotions)(Hatfield et al., 1993). The fear and distress experienced by one person may be unconsciously mirrored by others, thus leading to a spread of these emotions throughout society. In our deeply interconnected and digitalized world, these emotions may spread far more easily, as dire news from one corner of the world can influence people in another distant country by a myriad of news outlets, social media networks, videos and chat rooms(Gao et al., 2020). As a consequence of this, we may expect first peak of EEC in the community. There may also be an increase in the rate of relapse and recurrence of mental disorders in those already living with mental illness(Torales et al., 2020b). Furthermore, the stigma against mental health disorders, and inadequate mental health-related infrastructure, serve as additional barriers for those who are distressed to obtain help. This conceptual model is well supported by the existing literature(Ho et al., 2020; Li et al., 2020b; Lima et al., 2020; Liu et al., 2020; Neria et al., 2008). The time interval between the two peaks will be dependent on country specific measures and mitigation efforts. We note however, that in this model, we have not considered the appearance of the second wave of COVID-19 infections. In the event of this second wave, a second wave of EEC may have a more heterogeneous mixture of cases. It is thus imperative that this emotional contagion is prepared for by stakeholders at both national and international levels.
body_text.section: Conceptual Model of Emotional Epidemic Curve of Pandemic ::: Discussion

body_text.text: A MHSS enables systematic data collection, analysis, interpretation and the timely dissemination of the data to those responsible for prevention and control of the epidemic (Nsubuga et al., 2020) Unfortunately, at present there is no active MHSS in the sampled countries, except Iran, Italy and Tunisia. This MHSS must be strengthened to increase the likelihood of early detection and the tracking of mental health issues [18]. Continued virtual support and other innovative surveillance strategies (e.g., mobile app trackers and other mobile apps, screening tools) will benefit the public during a pandemic (considering the varying degrees of movement restriction and social distancing enforced) (Keesara et al., 2020; Li et al., 2020a; Xiang et al., 2020).
body_text.section: Mental Health Surveillance System (MHSS) ::: Preparation and coordination ::: Conceptual framework for Mental Health Preparedness and Action Framework (MHPAF) ::: Discussion

body_text.text: In the absence of a MHSS, countries will limit their opportunities to integrate and collaborate for global response and assistance, making it difficult to manage mental illnesses in the community. We recommend the establishment of a MHSS with teams (psychiatrist, psychologist and other mental health professionals) at different levels of service administration. The teams should coordinate Public Health, medical and emergency responses to enable the effective detection and management of common mental illnesses (Banerjee, 2020).
body_text.section: Mental Health Surveillance System (MHSS) ::: Preparation and coordination ::: Conceptual framework for Mental Health Preparedness and Action Framework (MHPAF) ::: Discussion

body_text.text:
PFA (developed by WHO) has been used in many countries as the primary psychological intervention of choice (WHO, 2011). However, most HCW are inadequately trained in the intervention. In addition, WHO-PFA does not address the primary mental health needs of the people under quarantine, those facing COVID-19 related social stigma, and those affected by national mitigation measures (social distancing, lockdowns, etc.). Furthermore, WHO-PFA provides little attention to managing myths and fake news, the impact of the virtual world on pandemic-related distress and the effects of the epidemic curve on mental health. Thus, it does not address the first peak of the EEC nor the second. It may also have poor face- and content-validity, all of which limits its use in practice. As such, we suggest the following modifications in the WHO-PFA (Ref. Box 1
) to address core mental health issues. Further tailoring of the PFA to the socio-cultural aspects of various nations may be required.Box 1Psychological first aid for Influenza (COVID-19)Pandemic.
1COVID-19 Pandemic: Brief overview, etiology, mode of transmission.2Self and family care – identify safe areas and constructive behavior to protect.3Primary information about COVID-19, preventive mental health and mental health promotion, mental health surveillance.4Information regarding official websites or mobile apps, radio, television, or printed material.5Learn the calming skills and maintenance of biological functions (e.g., nutrition, sleep, rest, exercise)6Maximize and facilitate connectedness to family and other social support systems to the extent possible (through electronic media rather than physical presence).7Foster hope and optimism.8Identification of red flags signs of deteriorating mental health – stage specific
Alt-text: Box 1
body_text.section: Psychological first aid (PFA) ::: Preparation and coordination ::: Conceptual framework for Mental Health Preparedness and Action Framework (MHPAF) ::: Discussion

body_text.text: Major alterations to existing mental health care services have been reported in all countries during this pandemic. We noted that most countries, except Iran, had yet to create COVID 19-specific mental health services. Special clinics should be created for COVID-19 patients. The possibility of tele-psychiatry or a virtual clinic can provide an opportunity to limit the attendance in outpatient services.
body_text.section: Special Cell or Clinics for mental health ::: Preparation and coordination ::: Conceptual framework for Mental Health Preparedness and Action Framework (MHPAF) ::: Discussion

body_text.text: The ECPs noted that primary health care workers could do with more training in conducting PFA. We recommend that frontline health workers should be trained in PFA and they must assume a leadership position in the dissemination of updated knowledge. This can be done digitally through webinars and video-conferencing.
body_text.section: Training ::: Preparation and coordination ::: Conceptual framework for Mental Health Preparedness and Action Framework (MHPAF) ::: Discussion

body_text.text: The MHSS team should prepare a well-circulated and written pandemic mental health emergency plan with special attention to the population at risk (HCW, pre-existing mental illness and quarantined or isolated population). In Italy, Brazil, Lebanon and Colombia such efforts have been undertaken.
body_text.section: Identification and Monitoring of the population at risk population ::: Monitoring and Assessment ::: Conceptual framework for Mental Health Preparedness and Action Framework (MHPAF) ::: Discussion

body_text.text: Tele-psychiatry apps, digital platforms, and dedicated hotlines have the potential to reduce the treatment gap(Xiang et al., 2020; Yao et al., 2020). These apps were used in Italy, which were aimed at assessing, evaluating and providing psychological and psychiatric support to vulnerable peoples. MHSS should be equipped with such apps for monitoring and assessment in all phases of pandemic.
body_text.section: Health care technology for assessment and monitoring ::: Monitoring and Assessment ::: Conceptual framework for Mental Health Preparedness and Action Framework (MHPAF) ::: Discussion

body_text.text: Social media, television and radio are the most frequently used approaches by the government to address misinformation. The MHSS team, public health system and technical team (social media, media) should be well equipped for continuous monitoring and should address myths promptly. We note the innovative concept of Corona Warriors (a team of volunteers to monitor social media sites to check for rumors) and the creation of a chatbot (Standard, 2020). The success and sustainability of Corona Warrior will be limited if not integrated as part of a MHSS team. However, mental health preparedness and response were not included in these Chabots. The preventive tips about mental health, nearby surveillance centers and other vital information regarding mental health can be provided through these apps. In addition, global efforts should be attempted to develop technology based interventions with local translation/adaptations. These will bring the uniform approach to address the mental distress and myths.
body_text.section: Interventions ::: Reducing the mental distress due to misinformation and ‘myths’ ::: Conceptual framework for Mental Health Preparedness and Action Framework (MHPAF) ::: Discussion

body_text.text: Funds are critical for strengthening the country’s preparedness and response to a pandemic. Inadequate funding of mental health resources will affect mental health preparedness and the ability to mitigate against a surge of mental health related problems. We thus recommend that substantial funds should be allotted to mental health. It may help to reduce the burden of mental health disorders in both the first and second peak of EEC.
body_text.section: Funding ::: Sustainability of Mental Health Care Services ::: Conceptual framework for Mental Health Preparedness and Action Framework (MHPAF) ::: Discussion

body_text.text: In many countries, early career psychiatrists have been redeployed to provide medical services to COVID-19 patients. This can lead to serious consequences- inadequate preparation for the second wave of EEC, a lack of mental health workers, lack of mental health training and support to HCW.
body_text.section: Policy ::: Sustainability of Mental Health Care Services ::: Conceptual framework for Mental Health Preparedness and Action Framework (MHPAF) ::: Discussion

body_text.text: A lack of coordination and collaboration within the healthcare system can affect the delivery of mental health services during a pandemic(Banerjee, 2020). In most of the countries, there were few efforts taken to improve coordination amongst healthcare service providers. A broad, multi-disciplinary approach that sees relationships being established both within, and outside the medical fraternity (e.g. with law enforcement) is crucial to enhancing interventive strategies.
body_text.section: Coordination and collaboration ::: Sustainability of Mental Health Care Services ::: Conceptual framework for Mental Health Preparedness and Action Framework (MHPAF) ::: Discussion

body_text.text: Traditional media (e.g. television), social media (e.g. Facebook), phone calls and official websites are commonly used to disseminate the information about COVID-19. However, this information may not be accessible to those who are illiterate, remote or underprivileged. In such a scenario, caller tunes or recorded phone calls can be used.
body_text.section: Media ::: Communication ::: Conceptual framework for Mental Health Preparedness and Action Framework (MHPAF) ::: Discussion

body_text.text: Few countries (e.g. Iran and Italy) attempted to provide virtual support through Whatsapp, telegram, Skype, facebook and others. Integrating tele-psychiatry with virtual support groups may improve the accessibility and affordability of mental health services(Yao et al., 2020).
body_text.section: Virtual Support Groups ::: Communication ::: Conceptual framework for Mental Health Preparedness and Action Framework (MHPAF) ::: Discussion

body_text.text: We expect MHPAF to reduce the expected epidemic of mental issues if implemented and suitably resourced. It will help psychiatrists to prepare for the expected surge of serious mental disorders (e.g. suicide, depression). Some countries (e.g. Spain, Italy, Iran ) have already initiated the redeployment of young psychiatrists to units managing COVID-19 patients – this move may stymie preparations to manage the anticipated mental health surge. We thus recommend that redeployment efforts should be done with caution.
body_text.section: Probable Effect of MHPAF on Emotional Epidemiology of Pandemic ::: Discussion

body_text.text: In this study, ECPs from a broad swathe of nations were interviewed. This is especially important as ECPs are often heavily involved, at ground-level, in clinical mental health work and can offer key perspectives on mental health challenges. This is especially important as national level planning may, at times, not percolate down to service providers conducting front-line work. The heterogeneity between the nations from which the psychiatrists came from further strengthens the broad applicability of our framework across nations with varying socio-economic situations.
body_text.section: Strengths and Limitations ::: Discussion

body_text.text: We are mindful, however, that further validation will be needed. Admittedly, pandemics are difficult settings in which to conduct well planned and controlled trials(Benight and McFarlane, 2007). Nonetheless, our conceptual framework can be useful to researchers to develop future studies on the topic. This is especially as MHPAF is a semi-structured framework and thus provides the opportunity to incorporate evidence-based interventions and the qualitative collection of data related to culture, health systems and other systems (legal, administrative and political).
body_text.section: Strengths and Limitations ::: Discussion

body_text.text: This framework considers the time frame of interest (starting point of disaster to recovery trajectory). Thus, it can be used to frame various research and policy questions in advance. However, there is a need to define key terms and construct analytic strategies. In subsequent studies, we are planning to explore various components of this framework to evaluate process indicators, challenges and barriers as well as outcome evaluation in selected countries.
body_text.section: Strengths and Limitations ::: Discussion

body_text.text: This conceptual framework is not a “one-size-fits-all” approach to mental health needs during a pandemic but provides a means by which national health care stakeholders can prepare for a potential rise in mental health issues. Further explorative studies with contemporary literature reviews and analytic strategies are needed to develop an effective preparedness and response plan to strengthen the response to pandemics at both national and global level.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: The authors declare that there was no funding for this work.
